channel.title: Polluted Runoff: Nonpoint Source Pollution
channel.description: Updated Polluted Runoff: Nonpoint Source Pollution content from the US Environmental Protection Agency

item.title: Nonpoint Source News-Notes, Issue 100, October 2016
item.description:
News-Notes is a periodic report on the Condition of the Water-Related Environment, the Control of Nonpoint Sources of Water Pollution, and the Ecological Management and Restoration of Watersheds

  • Nonpoint Source News-Notes, Issue100, October 2016 (PDF)(26 pp, 3 MB)
item.dc:creator: ccurtis

item.title: Nonpoint Source Highlights Report
item.description:
This report offers a glimpse of NPS activities underway across the United States supported by ยง319 and the people who are making it happen. It highlights the key issues and provides a snapshot of strategies that state agencies, territories and tribes are using to tackle the spectrum of water quality issues related to NPS pollution

  • National Nonpoint Source Program - a Catalyst for Water Quality Improvements (PDF)(24 pp, 19 MB, December 6, 2016, 841-R-16-009)
    A report on the highlights of the 319 program
item.dc:creator: ccurtis

item.title: Nonpoint Source Technical Exchange
item.description:
The State Nutrient Redcutions Strategies Web series is merging with the Nonpoint Source Technical Exchange forum to cover a broader variety of NPS topics.ย

  • Future Webinars
  • Past Webinars

Next Webinar:

February 2017 ย2-3:30pm Easternย

How to Attend the Webinars

EPA is using Adobe Connect for these webinars. You do not need to register in advance (in fact, you can't register in advance).

Follow this link and choose "Enter as a Guest".ย
You'll be prompted to enter your name and then Enter Room to join the webinar.

If you have never attended an Adobe Connect meeting before,test your connection first.

Future Webinars

Decemberยย7 1:00-3:00ยCentralย
Characterizing Recovery from Non-point Pollution: Landscape and Programmatic Factors related to delisting impaired waterbodies

Ari Engelberg, USEPA ORISE

January 18ย100-3:00ยCentralย
Speaker and Topic Forthcoming

March 1 1:00-3:00ยCentralย
Speaker and Topic Forthcoming

Past webinars

  • December 7, 2016 - Characterizing Recovery from Non-point Pollution: Landscape and Programmatic Factors related to delisting impaired waterbodies (PDF)(39 pp, 4 MB)
    Ari Engelberg, US EPA ORISE
  • October 26, 2016 - Nonpoint Source Watershed Project Resources (PDF)(63 pp, 4 MB)
    Steve Dressing, Tetratech, Inc.
  • July 13, 2016 - Conservation in Action in Idahoโs Treasure Valley (PDF)(40 pp, 3 MB)
    Mike Smith, CTIC and Terry Tindall, Simplot
  • April 12, 2016 - Agricultural Conservation Planning Framework: an Overview and Experience in Beargrass Creek and Silver Creek Watersheds (PDF)(96 pp, 33 MB)
    Mark Tomer, USDA, Agricultural Research Service Center: Janet Buchanan, Heartlands Conservancy; Joe Magner, University of Minnesota; Susan Stephan, Wabash County SWCD; Linda Prokopy, Purdue University
  • December 8, 2015 - Adjusting for Depreciation of Land Treatment When Planning Watershed Projects (PDF)(77 pp, 5 MB)
    Steven A. Dressing, Donald S. Meals, Tetra Tech, Inc.
item.dc:creator: ccurtis

item.title: Nonpoint Source News-Notes
item.description:
• Overview
  • Nonpoint News-Notes
  • NPS-INFO

    • ย

Nonpoint Source News-Notesยis anยoccasional bulletin dealing with the condition of the water-related environment, the control of nonpoint sources of water pollution (NPS), and the ecosystem-driven management and restoration of watersheds. It is produced by the Assessment and Watershed Protection Division, Office of Wetlands, Oceans, and Watersheds, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. Prior to Issue 70, News-Notes was produced by the Terrene Institute under an EPA Cooperative Agreement.

  • Subscribe

    To join NPS News-Notes Notification Service, send a message to:ยlyris@lists.epa.govยand include in the subject line or the body of the message: Subscribe NEWSNOTES [Your First Name] [Your Last Name]

    (e.g., Subscribe NEWSNOTES Jane Jones)

    You will receive emails only when a new issue is released (i.e., 2-3 times per year).

  • Unsubscribe

    To unsubscribe, send a blank message to news-notes-unsubscribe@lists.epa.gov from your subscription address.

  • Disclaimer of Endorsement

    Disclaimer of EndorsementยNonpoint Source News-Notes is produced by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, with support from Tetra Tech, Inc. Mention of commercial products, publications, or Web sites in this newsletter does not constitute endorsement or recommendation for use by EPA or its contractors, and shall not be used for advertising or product endorsement purposes.

Current Issue: Nonpoint Source News-Notes, Issue 100, October 2016

ย

Search News-Notes Issues Library

Use the following search box to search through all issues of News-Notes. To search for a literal phrase please enclose the words in double quotes (e.g., "rain garden").

item.title: Nonpoint Source News-Notes, Issue 99, January 2016
item.description:
News-Notes is a periodic report on the Condition of the Water-Related Environment, the Control of Nonpoint Sources of Water Pollution, and the Ecological Management and Restoration of Watersheds

  • January 2016, #99 (PDF)(24 pp, 2 MB)
item.dc:creator: mdillon

item.title: Using Low Impact Development and Green Infrastructure to Get Benefits From FEMA Programs
item.description:
EPA promotes the use of Low Impact Development (LID) and Green Infrastructure (GI) asยa cost-effective and resilient approach to stormwater management. LID/GI provides manyยcommunity benefits including cleaner water, wildlife habitat, enhanced aesthetics, and canยbe designed to supplement localized or watershed flood protection. LID/GI projects thatยreduce flood losses to properties insured under the National Flood Insurance Programย(NFIP) may be eligible for grant funding through the Federal Emergency ManagementยAgency (FEMA). In addition,ยLID/GI projects may allow aยcommunity to claim points toward flood inusrance discounts.

  • Get Flood Insurance Discounts with Low Impact Development, Open Space Protection Plans and Storm water Management Regulations (PDF)(2 pp, 340 K)
    LID/GI ordinances and other environmental planning may allow a community to claim points toward flood insurance discounts under the Community Rating System (CRS) developed by the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA).
  • Fund Low Impact Development/ Green Infrastructure Projects with FEMA Grants for Flood Mitigation (PDF)(2 pp, 535 K)
    LID/GI projects that reduce flood losses to properties insured under the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) may be eligible for grant funding through the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA).
item.dc:creator: ccurtis
